source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: The mid to late 1950s saw the first significant studies of zirconium alloys for nuclear applications in the UK. The first use was as cladding on the fuel elements for nuclear submarines, with minor applications of high-strength zirconium-copper-iron $( \mathbf { Z r C u F e } )$ and zirconium-copper-molybdenum (ZrCuMo) alloys as support beams in Magnox reactors.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: The mid to late 1950s saw the first significant studies of zirconium alloys for nuclear applications in the UK. The first use was as cladding on the fuel elements for nuclear submarines, with minor applications of high-strength zirconium-copper-iron $( \mathbf { Z r C u F e } )$ and zirconium-copper-molybdenum (ZrCuMo) alloys as support beams in Magnox reactors.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: In Sweden, the Ågesta pressurized heavy water reactor started operation with Zircaloy-2 fuel cladding and shroud tubes in 1964 and operated successfully for many years after early fretting problems.

extra_properties.operational_performance: successful for many years after early fretting problems

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: Behind this irradiation testing program lay a lot of alloy and tubing development, from its manufacturing route (three UK and one U.S. supplier were used), texture, tensile strength and ductility, creep strength, corrosion and hydrogen pickup, hydrogen solubility limits, and hydride orientation [49].

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: Very soon, a series of UK irradiation experiments were loaded, involving many design and materials variants including Zr-1Nb cladding, $0 . 3 8 – \mathrm { m m }$ wall cladding, hollow pellets, spacer grid variants, uranium metal fuel, and a number of instrumented fuel rods to measure stack length change and fission gas release.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk2
evidence_span: In the UK development program, a range of alloys was tested, including Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4, both cold-worked and stress-relieved (CwSR) and recrystallized, Zr-1Nb, z_{r-2}\% \mathrm{Nb}, Zr-3Nb-1Sn, ZrCrFe, and Ozhennite 0.5.
corrosion_data: none was significantly better than CwSR Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk2
evidence_span: In the UK development program, a range of alloys was tested, including Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4, both cold-worked and stress-relieved (CwSR) and recrystallized, Zr-1Nb, z_{r-2}\% \mathrm{Nb}, Zr-3Nb-1Sn, ZrCrFe, and Ozhennite 0.5.
corrosion_data: none was significantly better than CwSR Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk2
evidence_span: In the UK development program, a range of alloys was tested, including Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4, both cold-worked and stress-relieved (CwSR) and recrystallized, Zr-1Nb, z_{r-2}\% \mathrm{Nb}, Zr-3Nb-1Sn, ZrCrFe, and Ozhennite 0.5.
corrosion_data: showed promise, despite heavy corrosion in weld regions

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk3
evidence_span: Hydrogen pickup is a more serious problem in pressure tubes, as used in SGHWR, CANDU, and RBMK reactors, especially in any cool regions or if the reactor is cooled down under pressure.

extra_properties.problem_description: H2 segregation to cooler surfaces leading to zirconium hydride buildup

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk3
evidence_span: Hydrogen pickup during nodular corrosion is very low and this, together with the good thermal conductance through this porous type of oxide, minimizes the effect of relatively thick oxidation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk3
evidence_span: Alloys 1 and 2 were $1 \%$ niobium, Alloys 3 and 4 were 1 and $0 . 5 \%$ ,respectively, of niobium with $0 . 5 \%$ chromium, and Alloys 5 and 6 were $0 . 5 \%$ niobium with $0 . 3 \%$ molybdenum and $0 . 3 \%$ chromium plus $0 . 2 \%$ molybdenum [13].

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk3
evidence_span: Alloys 1 and 2 were $1 \%$ niobium, Alloys 3 and 4 were 1 and $0 . 5 \%$ ,respectively, of niobium with $0 . 5 \%$ chromium, and Alloys 5 and 6 were $0 . 5 \%$ niobium with $0 . 3 \%$ molybdenum and $0 . 3 \%$ chromium plus $0 . 2 \%$ molybdenum [13].

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk3
evidence_span: The SCANUK alloys were superior at high temperatures and showed less $\mathbf { H } _ { 2 }$ absorption than Zircaloy-2.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk3
evidence_span: The molybdenum bearing Alloys 5 and 6, chosen for high temperature strength, were disappointing in their corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk3
evidence_span: Alloys 3 and 4, the NbCr alloys had the best all-round performance and certainly compared favorably with Zircaloy-2.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk3
evidence_span: A threshold of 500 MPa was established in UKAEA gas pressurization tests, for cold-worked stress-relieved Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk3
evidence_span: other recent work suggests that the threshold stress reduces with irradiation, probably to a minimum of about $2 0 0 \ \mathbf { M P a }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: duplex cladding tube is used with a thin bore surface layer of pure soft zirconium

extra_properties.application: bore surface layer in duplex cladding
extra_properties.function: yields at stress below threshold to prevent cracking

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 tubing with a predominantly radial basal pole texture

extra_properties.performance: optimum for resisting iodine stress-corrosion cracking

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: INTER-RAMP, OVER-RAMP, DEMO-RAMP I and II, SUPERRAMP, SUPER-RAMP EXTENSION, and TRANS-RAMP I and II
conditions: BWR and PWR designs, burn-up 10 to 40 GWd/Tu

extra_properties.test_projects: INTER-RAMP, OVER-RAMP, DEMO-RAMP I and II, SUPERRAMP, SUPER-RAMP EXTENSION, TRANS-RAMP I and II
extra_properties.design_variations: type, condition, and thickness of cladding, pellet design, pellet density and grain size, filling gas pressure

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: some rods failed at a RTL between 30 and 35 kW/m with a power increment of only 10 to 15 kW/m, while others survived a ramp to over 60 kW/m with a power increment of over 30 kW/m
conditions: various ramp terminal levels and power increments

extra_properties.fission_gas_release: up to 50% in some surviving rods

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: maximum clad temperature, 1477 K, and maximum local cladding oxidation of 17%

extra_properties.safety_criteria: maximum clad temperature 1477K, maximum local oxidation 17%

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: Maximum clad strains were found at about 1125 K, just below the α to β transus, and could exceed 100% diameter increase
conditions: temperature ~1125 K, α to β transus region

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: The largest strains were seen in Test MT-3, reaching about 95% and significant strains occurred over about 0.75 m, with co-planar strains up to about 50% existing over 0.1 m

extra_properties.spacer_grid_effect: maximum strains at downstream end of inter-grid span

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: A 200-mm-long parallel section had a 50% clad strain (blockage factor 90%) with upstream and downstream conical tapers of 200 and 50 mm, respectively

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: In worst cases, there could be up to a 10-s delay in the cooling of blocked regions compared with by-pass regions, and the maximum peak temperature difference was 50 to 100 K

extra_properties.heat_transfer_effectiveness: disruption of parallel flow with water droplet impingement

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk6
evidence_span: peak clad temperature did not exceed 875 K

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk6
evidence_span: the cladding had oxidized through from the outside and structural changes indicated that the cladding temperature had exceeded 875 K

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk6
evidence_span: only a small reduction in elongation in closed-end burst tests on samples with 340 ppm hydrogen

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk6
evidence_span: A maximum level of 1.5 mg H₂ per fuel rod was set by UKAEA

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk7
evidence_span: This process is a volume-conserving type of stress-free creep. Some intergranular stresses are generated at grain boundaries, because of differences in orientation and the anisotropy of thermal expansion, but they are not sufficient to cause significant creep strain.

extra_properties.irradiation_growth_mechanism: volume-conserving stress-free creep with interstitial absorption enabling dislocation climb
extra_properties.grain_boundary_stresses: generated due to orientation differences and thermal expansion anisotropy
extra_properties.high_fluence_behavior: additional mechanism operates at high fluences and high temperatures

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_006_chunk8
evidence_span: Zirconium alloys are susceptible to a stable cracking process called delayed hydride cracking (DHC). DHC has two stages: (a) crack initiation that requires a minimum crack driving force (the threshold stress intensity factor, $K _ { I H } )$ and $( b )$ stable crack growth that is weakly dependent on $K _ { I }$
conditions: irradiation temperatures 250-290°C, fast neutron fluxes (E≥1 MeV) 1.6×10¹⁷ to 1.8×10¹⁸ n/m²·s, fluences 0.01×10²⁵ to 9.8×10²⁵ n/m²
